qas.question: In what year did the Endangered Species Act become law?
Which president signed the Act into law?
Which two federal agencies administer the Act?

answers.text: the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)

qas.question: On what day was the Endangered Species Act signed?
What did the Supreme Court cite as the intent of Congress in enacting the Endangered Species Act?

answers.text: to halt and reverse the trend toward species extinction, whatever the cost

qas.question: What did the Supreme Court sign into law in the 1970s?
Who is the President of the FWS?
What day did the Supreme Court rule on ESA?
Who ruled on which agencies would administer the act?

context: <b6_0>The Endangered Species Act<b6_0/> of <a0_0>1973<a0_0/> (ESA; 16 U.S.C. § 1531 et seq.) is one of the few dozens of United States environmental laws passed in the <b5_0>1970s<b5_0/>, and serves as the enacting legislation to carry out the provisions outlined in The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). The ESA was signed into law by President <a1_0><b7_0>Richard Nixon<b7_0/><a1_0/> on <a3_0><b8_0>December 28<b8_0/><a3_0/>, 1973, it was designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a "consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation." <b9_0>The U.S. Supreme Court<b9_0/> found that "the plain intent of Congress in enacting" the ESA "was <a4_0>to halt and reverse the trend toward species extinction, whatever the cost<a4_0/>." The Act is administered by two federal agencies, <a2_0>the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)<a2_0/>.
